Suppose you decided to create
a class called Apartment

that holds data about apartments
in an apartment building.
Suppose you decide that the data

that you need includes
an apartment number

and a monthly rent
for the apartment.

You might create a method,
such as set apartment number,

that accepts a parameter
that you can assign
to the apartment number.

And similarly, you might
have a method named set rent

that accepts an amount for the
monthly rent and assigns it
to the rent in the apartment.

You might also have
a display method

that outputs the data
in a nice format.

And that would be
the apartment class.

Suppose you had a program that
declares two apartment objects.

You might declare my
apartment as an apartment.

That would set up my apartment
in memory at a specific address.

Let's just say it's
memory address 1000.

And enough space
would be reserved

to eventually hold an
apartment number and the rent.

If you declare another object,
let's say your apartment,

that sets up another
spot in memory.

Let's just say it's at
memory address 1020.

And there would be
enough room there

to store an apartment number
and a rent for that apartment.

When you call an instance
method, you use an object,
a dot and a method name.

So, for example, my apartment
dot set apartment number can be

used to set the apartment
number of my apartment.

When you call the set
apartment number method,

a this reference is
passed to the method.

The this reference is not
something that you code

in the method, but it's sent
implicitly, and it's going
to hold the address

of the object whose apartment
number is going to be sent.

So when you call my apartment
dot set apartment number,

the address of my apartment
1000 is sent to the method

so the method knows
what object to work on.

The argument to the method
107 is sent in as a parameter
for the apartment number.
When you call the method,

the apartment number is
actually this apartment number.

You don't have to write this
in the method, but this refers

to this object at address
1000, its apartment number.
So the argument that comes

in as the parameter
107 can be assigned

to the apartment
number at address 1000.

Similarly, you can call
my apartment dot set rent
and send in an argument.

And a this reference is
used in the method header.

And a this reference can be
used within the method itself.

So when you call my apartment
dot set rent, it gets the 1000,

which is the address
of my apartment,

it sends it to the method, the
rent is also sent to the method,

and the value is assigned
at 1000's rent location.

So 600 goes into my
apartment's rent.

When you call my
apartment display,

a this reference is accepted by
the method, and this can be used

with the apartment number
and the rent to indicate

which object's data
will be displayed.

When you call my apartment
dot display, 1000 is sent

in as the reference, and the
data that's accessed is this
apartment number and this rent.

So the output becomes
apartment number 107 rents
for $600 per month.
